description: Iraq has extended the suspension of all flights in and out of the country until March 28. UPDATE: The original suspension of flights was until March 24; it has been extended until March 28.

Iraq on Monday, June 8,  extended the suspension of commercial flights in and out of the country until Saturday, June 13, to curb further the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Qatar Airways has previously offered occasional special charter flights when granted permission from Iraqi authorities.

Iraq on Monday, June 8,  extended the suspension of commercial flights in and out of the country until Saturday, June 13, to curb further the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Qatar Airways has previously offered occasional special charter flights when granted permission from Iraqi authorities. 
The ban was re-extended from the 13th of June to 1st July, 15th July and 22d July. Although medical evacuation and air freight operations are exempt from the ban. Commercial flights by Iraqi Airways between Beirut and Baghdad have also been exempted from the ban. UPDATE: Iraqi authorities extended the commercial flight ban from the 13th of June to July 1st, then to July 15th and then to July 22d. Medical evacuation and air freight operations were exempt from the ban. Commercial flights by Iraqi Airways between Beirut and Baghdad have also been exempted from the ban.

Iraq on Monday, June 8,  extended the suspension of commercial flights in and out of the country until Saturday, June 13, to curb further the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Qatar Airways has previously offered occasional special charter flights when granted permission from Iraqi authorities. 
The ban was re-extended from the 13th of June to 1st July, 15th July and 22d July. Although medical evacuation and air freight operations are exempt from the ban. Commercial flights by Iraqi Airways between Beirut and Baghdad have also been exempted from the ban.

From July 6, Iraqis will be permitted to travel abroad. Upon returning, "Iraqi nationals must undergo both clinical and rapid Covid-19 tests. Those who test negative, must self-quarantine at home for 14 days. Those who test positive or show symptoms of Covid-19, will be transferred to specialist hospitals"
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

The Iraqi Border Crossing Authority announced that the border crossing will reopen two days a week for trade and cargo exchange only.

description:
The Iraqi authorities on July 16,  announced that airports will re-open as of Thursday, July 23 for commercial flights. The airport administration has made wearing masks, hand gloves mandatory for all workers and passengers. It has also taken steps to ensure that workers and passengers maintain social distancing according to the recommendations of the World Health Organization. Thermal temperature screening is in place at airport entrances and for arriving passengers.  Individuals exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19 and/or those not wearing face coverings may be denied boarding or entry to the airport.
Passengers departing Iraq may be required to provide negative COVID-19 test results prior to departure depending on the country of destination. Those departing to locations with COVID-19 test requirements may be required to provide negative results within the specified time frame of the destination. individuals traveling to Iraq are required to carry out a COVID-19 test 48 hours prior to the flight and should be prepared to present results at passport control.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Iraqi border crossing to Iran in Shalamija was closed from July 31 until Aug. 8 as part of measures to stem the spread of coronavirus. On the 9th of August, it was announced that the crossing will reopen for commercial activity. "Around 250 trucks will cross the terminal from Sunday to Wednesday every week,” Alaa al-Din al-Qaisi, spokesperson for the Iraqi Border Crossing Authority.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: The Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) announced on Monday, July 27, that any passengers traveling from Erbil (EBL) and Sulaimani (ISU) international airports in the Kurdistan region must test negative for the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) to be permitted to fly. Passengers must be tested for COVID-19 48 hours before their flight. Passengers will need to pay for their test, which cost 100,000 Iraqi dinars (84 USD). The airports of Erbil and Sulaymaniyah are expected to reopen on Saturday, August 1.

description:
On March 26 the Iraqi government Crisis Cell issued the following guidance update in relations to Covid-19:
Those who have influenza-like symptoms should contact their nearest health centre as soon as possible.
On March 22, Iraq allocated $50 million to the Ministry of Health to import medicine and medical supplies.
On March 25, Iraq has opened a new laboratory for testing suspected coronavirus cases.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From March 26, Iraq has allowed health professionals to delay their retirement to "continue in their posts for the duration of the crisis".
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Iraq: In cooperation with the World Health Organization (WHO), the COVID-19 Crisis Cell of Basrah University produced laboratory supplies to speed up testing of suspected cases. As of 1 April, the University manufacturing team produced more than 1620 VTM, in addition to 3200 nasal swabs. These were delivered to health directorates in Iraq’s Basra, Muthana, Karbala, and Wasit governorates.
This production, along with the Reverse Transcriptase-PRC (RT-PCR) kits provided by WHO, has facilitated the testing of hundreds of suspected cases in southern Iraq.
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country
enforcer: New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Iraq: As of April 1 three laboratories became operational for COVID-19 testing in Najaf, Basra, and Medical City in Baghdad.
enforcer: National Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Iraq: The Basrah Crisis Cell has also announced 3 other COVID-19 response measures, including an online application for COVID-19 self-reporting. So far, the app has been used by 4500 applicants, of whom 130 qualified for further testing by the RT-PCR kits.
From April 2, Iraq is exempting "all medicines, medical supplies and devices, diagnostic and laboratory equipment from import license regulations".
During Ramadan, Iraq has mandated that everyone wear a face mask "outside the home" or face legal penalty.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From June 29, Iraq will "allow a number of accredited private laboratories to conduct Covid-19 tests based on the strict criteria set by the Ministry of Health".
From June 29, Iraq will provide additional funding for the Ministry of Health to be used for the direct purchase of medicine and medical supplies and to recruit additional medical staff.

From June 29, Iraq has begun an effort to "coordinate with other countries which have announced that they are working on a potential treatments for Covid-19, and to negotiate with these countries to ensure that Iraq receives the necessary medicines and supplies".

description:
The Iraqi Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) has announced a “complete lockdown” starting at 12:00 pm on 4th April until April 6.
Interior ministry said that  “Vehicle and pedestrian movements will be completely banned in all the provinces of Erbil, Sulaimaniyah, Duhok, and Halabja,” .  Except for some pharmacies, all shops, bakeries, and other services will be closed down during the 48 hours of complete lockdown.

description:
Iraq’s Kurdistan region interior ministry decided on April 10 to extend the curfew imposed on Iraqi Kurdistan Region until April 16. Residents are only allowed outside to shop for food and essential supplies at their local shops, for medical reasons, or otherwise authorized by the government.
Travel restrictions do not include members of the security forces, health workers, UN agencies, and journalists.

description: Iraq: On Sunday, May 3, the crisis cell responsible for Kirkuk's province's response to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic announced it was imposing a full lockdown on the province from Monday, May 4, to Saturday, May 9. Under the lockdown entry into and exit out of the province will be prohibited, except for medical and media personnel. A 24-hour curfew will be in place and official working hours will be suspended.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Iraq: Areas of Baghdad believed to play a role in spreading the virus will face a full lockdown as of 20th of May to June 3, Health Minister Hassan al-Tamimi said in a statement.
The areas include Sadr City, Habibia, Hurriya, Shula, Ameria, and Kamalia.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: Iraq: The Iraqi Kurdistan Government announced a complete lockdown fron the 23d of May to 24th of May amid the Eid al Fitr celebration. o traffic will be allowed except security and medical services. Only pharmacies can operate during the full lockdown.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: Iraq has imposed a full lockdown across the country throughout the Eid Al-Fitr holiday, which is May 23 and 24.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: Iraq: on Sunday, May 31, the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) announced that a region-wide lockdown would be implemented until midnight on Saturday, June 6, following a rise in coronavirus disease (COVID-19) cases. The lockdown is to go into effect from the evening of Monday, June 1. All pedestrian and vehicular traffic will be restricted, with exemptions for media and healthcare workers. All religious sites and places of worship are to close as part of the lockdown.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: Iraq: A 24 hr lockdown imposed in multiple provinces. On Tuesday, June 23, authorities in multiple Iraqi provinces introduced a comprehensive curfew and closed their borders in an attempt to limit the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). The provinces affected are Karbala, Qadisiyah, Babel, Dhi Qar, Maysan, Basra, Nineveh, and Anbar; the new measures will remain in effect for seven days.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: Iraq: Authorities announced that a total lockdown will be imposed in Erbil from Tuesday, June 30, due to an increase in locally-detected cases of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). The order will come into effect as of 06:00 (local time) on Tuesday and will remain in place until 23:59 on Saturday, July 4. The lockdown prohibits all civilian movements, with residents only being permitted to travel to purchase food and collect medicine. Only military, humanitarian, diplomatic, emergency services and transport linked to the oil industry will be permitted to move freely during this period. Non-commercial transport between Erbil province and other areas of the Kurdistan region is also prohibited.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: Iraq due to the Eid al-Adha holiday imposed a total curfew from July 30 until Aug. 9.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Iraq has created a new committee on April 2 to assess current and future needs in terms of medical supplies, food, and agricultural produce.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: From March 15, the Iraqi Ministry of Health directed "relevant authorities" to fumigate and disinfect areas and districts affected by the coronavirus.
type_text: This policy from the Iraqi Ministry of Health issued on March 15 directs the relevant authorities to conduct sanitation campaigns performing fumigation/disinfection in areas/districts affected by the coronavirus.

description: From March 26, Iraq is calling on religious authorities to assist in providing safe, dignified burials in accordance with "the necessary health precautions".
type_text: The policy addresses the need for "the collecting, casketing, and transporting of bodies" of COVID-19 patients to follow "necessary health precautions" and calls on the help of religious authorities.
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Iraqi cabinet agreed on a number of economic measures to mitigate the impact of Covid-19:
Suspending all repayments due on residential plots of land sold or leased to citizens from all government institutions until the end of the current emergency, with no penalty interest for a period ending on 31/07/2020 at the latest
Exempting commercial, industrial and other government real estate tenants from paying rental fees for the duration of the current emergency
Exempting occupants and tenants of commercial, industrial and other properties that belong to municipal institutions  from paying cleaning services fees for the duration of the emergency
type_text: The policies are economic designed to relive financial strain from mainly from government employees.

description: Iraq: The Higher Committee for Health and National Safety, announced on April 11 that the Iraqi government was making available a temporary monthly grant to those affected by the nationwide curfew and other restrictions. The grant is only available to Iraqi citizens who are residing in Iraq. Government employees, those receiving state pensions, social security payments or any other income from the state are not eligible to apply. Those eligible can apply to receive the grant via a dedicated website, minha.iq between Saturday 11 April and midday on Thursday 16 April.
type_text: A grant to relieve financial strain from Iraqi citizens.

description: Iraq has decided to make a monthly bonus payment to "frontline health teams who are caring for Covid-19 patients" and award a free-of-charge "plot of land to all health workers who are caring for Covid-19 patients".
type_text: The policy rewards health-care workers caring for COVID-19 patients by providing them monthly bonus payments and free plots of land.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Iraq has released 20,040 detainees to "reduc[e] the risks of the spread of the coronavirus."
type_text: The policy releases some detainees to limit the spread of COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 2, Iraq decided to protect students from Covid-19 by allowing primary school students graduate to intermediate education based on their half-term exam scores.
type_text: The policy allows primary school students to move to intermediate education despite their end-of-year exams being cancelled due to COVID-19.

description: As a reward for health staff working with COVID-19 patients, Iraq has directed "the Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research to allocate additional places on postgraduate courses for health staff wishing to pursue further studies."
type_text: This policy rewards health staff treating COVID-19 patients by offering extra places in university courses reserved for health staff.

description: On June 23, Iraq decided to protect students from Covid-19 by allowing intermediate school students to graduate to secondary school based on their half-term exam scores.
type_text: The policy allows intermediate school students to move to secondary education despite their end-of-year exams being cancelled due to COVID-19.

description: Erbil, Iraq, 25 August 2020 – The World Health Organization (WHO) has delivered 6 ambulances to the Ministry of Health of the Kurdistan region to improve ambulatory and life-saving services for the vulnerable population of Syrian refugees and the host community in the Erbil governorate of Iraq.
type_text: Erbil, Iraq, 25 August 2020 – The World Health Organization (WHO) has today delivered 6 ambulances to the Ministry of Health of the Kurdistan region to improve ambulatory and life-saving services for the vulnerable population of Syrian refugees and the host community in the Erbil governorate of Iraq.
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On Feb. 22, 2020, the Ministry of Health in Iraq issued preventative health guidance to the public regarding COVID-19.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: From 9 March, Iraq implemented a campaign to distribute information on COVID-19 in Kurdish and Arabic to those working with IDP populations to allow them to take preventative action.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Iraq: The Iraq crisis cell in partnership with the WHO  issued guidance for  “safe Ramadan practices in the context of the Covid-19 pandemic”.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Iraq started A one-month public awareness campaign, which began on 29 June, targeted more than 6 million people in 10 heavily populated and COVID-19-affected districts in Baghdad with health promotion and awareness messages to limit transmission of COVID-19 following an increase in the number of cases reported in the country. The campaign dubbed "Your health is important" was conducted in each of the 10 districts for a period of 3 days and will be extended to Sulaymaniyah, Basra, Missan, Thi Qar, and Wasit on 9 August 2020 and target areas reporting a high number of cases.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Iraq started A one-month public awareness campaign, which began on 29 June, targeted more than 6 million people in 10 heavily populated and COVID-19-affected districts in Baghdad with health promotion and awareness messages to limit transmission of COVID-19 following an increase in the number of cases reported in the country. The campaign dubbed "Your health is important" was conducted in each of the 10 districts for a period of 3 days and will be extended to Sulaymaniyah, Basra, Missan, Thi Qar, and Wasit on 9 August 2020 and target areas reporting a high number of cases. UPDATE: The original campaign in the districts of Baghdad started on the June of the 29th and ended on July the 28th.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Iraq on the 9th of August, the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Ministry of Health of Iraq launched the second phase of a COVID-19 awareness-raising campaign in the heavily populated, high-risk areas of Thi Qar and Missan, south of Baghdad. This current phase of the campaign in Thi Qar and Misan will run from 9 to 12 August 2020.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Iraq on the 9th of August, the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Ministry of Health of Iraq launched the second phase of a COVID-19 awareness-raising campaign in the heavily populated, high-risk areas that will be extended in Basra, Wasit, and to Sulaymaniyah. The campaign will run from 16 to 10 September in intervals of 4 days each of the southern provinces and for 9 days in Sulaymaniyah.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From March 9, Iraq has requested that Iraqi citizens returning from Iran, China, South Korea, Italy, Japan, Thailand, Singapore, Kuwait and Bahrain should self-quarantine at home for 14 days.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From April 8, Iraq is requiring repatriated Iraqis returning from low-risk countries (less than 500 COVID-19 cases per million people) to be examined at the border. Suspicious cases will be transferred to hospitals for testing; all others will be required to self-quarantine at home, during which time security and health authorities will follow up on their condition and the Ministry of the Interior will keep their passports.

description: From Feb. 27 until March 7, Iraq has ordered the closure of cinemas, cafes, clubs, and other public gathering spots

Iraq has extended the closure of non-essential businesses until March 28 and expanded it to include all businesses other than pharmacies, medicine stores, food stores, bakeries and petrol stations. UPDATE: The closure of non-essential businesses has been extended until March 28 and expanded to include all businesses other than pharmacies, medicine stores, food stores, bakeries and petrol stations.

Iraq has extended the closure of all businesses excluding pharmacies, medicine stores, food stores, bakeries and petrol stations until April 11. UPDATE: The closure of non-essential businesses was originally set to last until March 28, it has been extended to April 11.
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Iraq has extended the closure of all businesses until May 22 with exceptions for pharmacies, medicine stores, food stores, bakeries and petrol stations, and new exceptions for shops and factories "outside curfew hours", taxis, and delivery services by restaurants and cafes. UPDATE: The closure of non-essential businesses has been extended again to May 22, but new exceptions have been added for stores and factories during daylight hours, taxis, and restaurants/cafes doing delivery.
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From April 28, shops and stores in Iraq will be permitted to have 1 customer for every 5 square meters, "allowing only those wearing a face mask to enter such premises. Shop owners will be subject to a 100,000 dinar fine if they do not comply with these regulations, and risk their shops being closed down."
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: From May 30, Iraq is mandating the closure of all businesses except for grocery stores, bakeries, banks, and pharmacies.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From May 30, Iraq has extended the policy that restaurants must be shut except for home delivery services.
Iraq is closing "all private doctors’ surgeries, medical clinics and centres for two weeks, starting from 07/07/20 until 20/07/20".

On September 8 the Iraqi Government announced that will allow restaurants, event halls and tourist facilities at five-star hotels to reopen,  provided that health preventive measures are put in place as directed by the Ministry of Health

description: On September 8 the Iraq Government announced that will allow ministries and official public institutions to work at 50% capacity, permit the Independent High Electoral Commission to open registration centres to allow voters to register for the biometric voting cards and exempt staff of the Independent High Electoral Commission from curfew regulations.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On Feb. 25, the Iraqi Ministry of Health advised people throughout Iraq to avoid all unnecessary public gatherings.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On Feb. 25, the Iraqi Ministry of Health advised people throughout Iraq to avoid all unnecessary public gatherings. UPDATE: On September 8 the Iraqi government announced that it will permit youth, sports activities and events in various fields (without the presence of spectators) while adhering to preventive health measures from 12/09/2020
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Iraq: Group events around Kirkuk banned for 15 days from February 26.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Iraq is banning all "gatherings in public places for any reason" and empowering "the relevant authorities" to enforce this measure from Feb. 26. UPDATE: The original ban on mass gatherings was recommended/voluntary, it is now mandatory (implied).
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Iraq banned all public gatherings and called on citizens to avoid visiting sacred cities and sites to stop the spread of the coronavirus from 2020/3/9.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: From April 21, in Iraq, "large public transport vehicles" will only be "permitted to carry four passengers at any one time".
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: From April 21, in Iraq, "large public transport vehicles" will only be "permitted to carry four passengers at any one time", and from April 28, public transport vehicles carrying more than four passengers or carrying passengers without face masks will be fined 50,000 dinars. UPDATE: The limitation on public transportation was mandatory (implied), it is now mandatory (fine).
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Iraq: On Monday,11th May, the Kurdish region administration reopened all mosques for the daily five prayers and Tarawih, special night prayers performed during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Iraq: On April 28 the government announced that there will be a fine of 50,000 dinars on public transport vehicles carrying more than 4 passengers, and on saloon cars carrying more than 3 passengers. The drivers of the vehicles will also be fined if their passengers do not wear face masksImposing a fine of 10,000 dinars on each individual not wearing a face mask in public. Shop owners must only have 1 customer for every 5 square metres of space in shops and stores and all customers to have masks, otherwise they will face a 100,000 dinar fine
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: Iraq: On April 28 the government announced that there will be a fine of 50,000 dinars on public transport vehicles carrying more than 4 passengers, and on saloon cars carrying more than 3 passengers. The drivers of the vehicles will also be fined if their passengers do not wear face masksImposing a fine of 10,000 dinars on each individual not wearing a face mask in public. Shop owners must only have 1 customer for every 5 square metres of space in shops and stores and all customers to have masks, otherwise they will face a 100,000 dinar fine
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: From May 5, Iraq has decided that, to combat the coronavirus pandemic, "based on even and odd numbered license plates, vehicles will be allowed on roads and public highways on alternate days."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: From May 5, Iraq has decided that, to combat the coronavirus pandemic, "based on even and odd numbered license plates, vehicles will be allowed on roads and public highways on alternate days."
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: In the Iraqi Kurdistan Region (IKR), Decree #48 dated August 20, 2020 imposes a 20,000 Iraqi dinar fine (approximately 17USD) on individuals “seen outside” without a mask. The decree also obligates private sector institutions to require employees to wear masks and requires masks of passengers in vehicles.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
